title: Radnor Forest Walks and Cycling

images.title: Richard Webb / The Radnor Forest
images.caption: View along the Dolau - New Radnor road with smooth steep slopes on Great Rhos at the head of Cwm Merwys. Wimberry plants provide the lurid green.

images.title: Richard Webb / Radnor Forest
images.caption: Radnor Forest is a hunting forest and has long been without much tree cover. However the northern and eastern slopes of the central block of hills was chosen as one of the first sites to be planted by the Forestry Commission in the 1920s. View down towards Cascob.

images.title: Graham Horn / Towards Radnor Forest
images.caption: It is only 300 metres as the crow flies to the corner of the forest. But there is a great valley in the way, covered in heather.

images.title: Jonathan Billinger / Bridleway into the Radnor Forest
images.caption: Bridleway into the Radnor Forest. View east of the A44 looking towards a conifer copse on the edge of the gridsquare.

images.title: Richard Webb / Track on the Radnor Forest
images.caption: The farmers have nibbled away at the moorland and these improved fields are quite high (460m asl). Beside the tracks is a mixen, ready to help maintain the fertility. The fields are densely stocked with Welsh Mountain sheep.

images.title: Bill Rowley / The 'Three Riggles' - Radnor Forest
images.caption: The 'Three Riggles'. Although there is a photo of the Three Riggles and a warning sign on the adjoining square (SO1962)the major part of the Three Riggles falls within this square and therefore deserves its own picture.

description: A long distance shared walking and cycle path that runs from Llanfair Waterdine on the English-Welsh border to the Brecon Beacons Visitor Centre. It will take you through the expansive area of the Radnor Forest located to the north of the Black Mountains and to the east of the Cambrian Mountains. The forest is noted for its photogenic geology and a wide variety of interesting flora and fauna. The path follows a series of bridleways and minor country roads through some wonderful scenery including the beautiful Wye Valley and the spectacular Brecon Beacons.
